statement.title: Problem Description
statement.content: A regular convex polygon is a polygon where each side has the same length, and all interior angles are equal and less than 180 degrees. A square, for example, is a regular convex polygon. You are given three points which are vertices of a regular convex polygon R; can you determine the minimum number of vertices that R must have?

statement.title: Input
statement.content: Each test case consists of three lines. Line i consists of two floating point values x<sub>i</sub> and y<sub>i</sub> (-10<sup>4</sup> <=x<sub>i</sub>,y<sub>i</sub><=10<sup>4</sup>) where (x<sub>i</sub>,y<sub>i</sub>) are the coordinates of a vertex of R. The coordinates are given with a precision of 10<sup>-6</sup>, i.e., they differ from the exact coordinates by at most 10<sup>-6</sup>. You may assume that for each test case the Euclidean distance between any two given points is at least 1, and R has at most 1000 vertices. The input will finish with a line containing the word END.

statement.title: Output
statement.content: For each test case, print one line with the minimum number of vertices that R must have.
